title: VirtualBox: IPv6 fix causes issues on Linux
body:
On Linux, interfaces are auto-configured with Link Local Addresses (`fe:*`). When a VirtualBox host-only interface without an IPv6 address is created, it would still get an `fe:*` address. This causes VirtualBox to attempt to reach such addresses. The problem arises when the interface does not have any virtual machine attached to it. For example, I have a network adapter with IPv4 configured with no VMs:

```
Name:            vboxnet4
GUID:            786f6276-656e-4474-8000-0a0027000004
DHCP:            Disabled
IPAddress:       192.168.60.1
NetworkMask:     255.255.255.0
IPV6Address:     fe80:0000:0000:0000:0800:27ff:fe00:0004
IPV6NetworkMaskPrefixLength: 64
HardwareAddress: 0a:00:27:00:00:04
MediumType:      Ethernet
Status:          Up
VBoxNetworkName: HostInterfaceNetworking-vboxnet4
```

It does have an IPv6 address, but that's an auto-configured address (not something I setup). The interface itself is up, but is not in the RUNNING state at this point and attempting to reconfigure it fails:

```
vboxnet4: flags=4099<UP,BROADCAST,MULTICAST>  mtu 1500
        inet6 fe80::800:27ff:fe00:4  prefixlen 64  scopeid 0x20<link>
        ether 0a:00:27:00:00:04  txqueuelen 1000  (Ethernet)
```

vagrant should only attempt to validate and reconfigure routes for interfaces that are actually in use by a machine, not just all interfaces. I will submit a PR to fix that.
